newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: India veg oil imports may rise by 300,000-400,000T.
newsitem.headline: India veg oil imports may rise by 300,000-400,000T.

text.p: India's vegetable oil imports are expected to rise by between 300,000-400,000 tonnes every year until the turn of the century as strong demand outpaces domestic production, industry officials said on Thursday.

"India's import requirements will rise sharply in the short run. Demand for edible oil will rise by 300,000 to 400,000 tonnes every year," G.G. Patel, President of the Solvent Extractors' Association of India, said at an edible oils conference in Singapore.
G.K. Sood, chief executive of the Vansapti Manufacturers Association of India, said in a report at the same meeting that domestic production of 11 oilseed crops is being outstripped by robust demand.
"The deficit of 1.5 million tonnes could rise to 2.2 million tonnes by 2000," he said.
"Demand for vegetable oils is expected to grow by 6.5 to 7.0 percent per annum. Production is, however, expected to lag behind with a growth rate of 4.5 percent," he added.
India's vegetable oil output in the (October/September) 1996/97 season is estimated to reach 7.3 million tonnes.
Consumption stands at about 9.35 million tonnes and is growing at an annual rate of two percent.
Patel said one area in which the government will have to play a more active role would be in the expansion of palm oil production by resolving legal issues on land holdings.
There is also a "clear lack of hedging or futures trading" facilities and an antiquated marketing system which "needs to be modernised," Patel said.
"Handling facilities at the ports, barring one or two, are primitive. Storage facilities are inadequate. congestion, berthing delays and demurrage claims are not unusual," he said.
